dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LISA LEMON, 34, walks up to the bagel store, reading the paper, wearing her ipod. Two Upper West Side moms chat, blocking the entrance with their enormous double strollers.

dialogues.speaker: MOM 1
dialogues.text: I nursed Zach til he was 22 months...

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: Excuse me...

dialogues.speaker: MOM 2
dialogues.text: Weren’t you worried about nipple confusion?

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: Excuse me...

dialogues.speaker: MOM 1
dialogues.text: No. He went right from my breast to a sippy cup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That happened to me once. Can I get by? They still don’t hear her.

dialogues.speaker: MOM 2
dialogues.text: What about silicone nipple shields? Lisa has no choice but to back up a few steps and take a running jump over the children and into the bagel place. The moms are appalled.

dialogues.speaker: MOM 1
dialogues.text: If you had kids, you would not be laughing!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lisa waits in a long line leading to two registers. A GUY on a cell phone enters. He ignores the line and goes up to the other register.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: Whoa, whoa, Excuse me. There’s a line, buddy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guy points to where he’s standing. Guy There‘s two lines.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: No, what? No. There’s one line, we’re in it. Guy I don’t think so. The guy goes back to talking on his cell phone. He holds his finger up to the counter girl to wait.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: You don’t think so? You think there‘s two lines and we all chose to be in this one and you’re the only genius who got in the other line? (looks to others) Do you believe this guy? The other people just shrug and avert their eyes. The back half of the line goes and lines up behind the guy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LISA (CONT’D) What are you doing?! He screws you over and now you’re lining up behind him? The stroller moms join the back of his line. They stare Lisa down. LISA (CONT’D) Will not one of you stand with me?i

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: Hey, shut up-- (into his phone) What kind do you want? Shut up?!! Lisa is now at the front of her line, boiling

dialogues.speaker: COUNTER GIRL
dialogues.text: Can I help you?

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: Yeah, I’1ll take everything. I want every bagel in this place. (to everyone) I’m buying all the bagels. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  Lisa hands her a credit card. The cell phone guy rolls his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: ALL
dialogues.text: What?! Come on, lady. Boo! Etc...

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: it's for the qood of everyone!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: “Old Skool” opening credit sequence to music in the style of “My Red Letter Day” from The Ziegfeld Follies. A beaming Lisa passes out bagels to everyone she sees. Some people are grateful. Most are mistrustful and throw them away as soon as she passes. She heads through town and ends up at 30 ROCKEFELLER PLAZA!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The studio's homebase set. Workmen are polishing a big sign that reads, "Friday Night Bits with Jenna DeCarlo,"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pull back through the picture window to where KENNETH a bright and chirpy (Clay Aiken type) NBC page is giving a tour. He stands next to a life-size standee of impish comedian Jenna DeCarlo. .

dialogues.speaker: KENNETH
dialogues.text: And this is the set of the "Friday Night Bits with Jenna DeCarlo." (points to standee) It's a real funny ladies’ comedy show for ladies.

dialogues.speaker: TOURIST
dialogues.text: What time is it on?

dialogues.speaker: KENNETH
dialogues.text: Fridays at 10. But, seriously, sir, it's just for ladies. Candy quiz! Can anybody name other shows that only ladies like?

dialogues.speaker: TOURIST
dialogues.text: Desperate Housewives? Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: KENNETH
dialogues.text: Yes. Kenneth throws the guy a piece of candy.

dialogues.speaker: TOURIST 2
dialogues.text: "Sex in The City?"

dialogues.speaker: KENNETH
dialogues.text: No. (throws candy) I’m sorry, it’s Sex and the City. I cannot accept that. Kenneth does not throw the guy candy. The elevator doors open and Lisa comes out, carrying one small bag of bagels.

dialogues.speaker: KENNETH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hey, everybody, here's someone you'd never get to meet. This is the head- writer of Friday Night Bits, Lisa Lemon. Kenneth claps. The tour group stares blankly. Lisa smiles embarrassedly and waves.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: Hi. Beat. A fat kid in the front burps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lisa xuns into PETE HORNBERGER, 43, her friend and longtime producer.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: What's up? Have you looked at that ‘“Judgemental Baby” sketch? Cause it’s still seven minutes long.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: Yikes, okay. Hey, you gotta tell that NBC page to take it down a notch.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Who Kenneth?

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: He just embarrassed me in front of a whole tour group. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll talk to him, (notices bagels) What's this?

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: (smiles) I was in the bagel store and this guy comes in--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At a large conference table, TOOFER, 25, an African- American Harvard guy writer and FRANK, 27, a heavyset writer with long 2% Top hair and glasses, read the papers. In the corner, SARIE, a gorgeous 22 year old assistant (of the spray-tanned platinum-haired Hilton variety) answers the phone.

dialogues.speaker: SARIE
dialogues.text: Friday Night Bits. Okay, hold on, I'll connect you. She somehow looks sexy transferring calls. Toofer and Frank stare at her. Next call.

dialogues.speaker: SARIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Friday Night Bits. Our fax number? Sarie kneels backwards on her chair to look at the fax machine, a lower back tattoo is revealed. _Toofer gives Frank $5 (clearly, they had a bet.) Lisa enters, finishing her story to Pete.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: And I was like, “Give me all the bagels, dammit!”

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: (takes bagel) Wow. That is the longest stroy I’ve ever had to listen to to get a free bagel. Pete continues down the hall. Toofer complains to Lisa immediately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  €

dialogues.speaker: TOOFER
dialogues.text: Chumley, you have got to talk to someone upstairs about getting us a stock of beverages.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: Good morning.

dialogues.speaker: TOOFER
dialogues.text: I mean, surely our massive conglomerate parent company could spring for a samovar of coffee. ,

dialogues.speaker: PRANK
dialogues.text: Or, like, a big coffee dispenser.

dialogues.speaker: TOOFER
dialogues.text: That's what a samovar is.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Sorry, I wasn’t raised gay. JOSH, 23, enters. He is an adorable young comedian/cast member on “The Jenna DeCarlo Show.”

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Hey, who does this sound like?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josh does a flawless imitation of President Bush.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: “My fellow Americans, the situation in Iraq grows more tense each day. The insurgeons and evil-spreaders has left me no choice but to ask for a do-over.”

dialogues.speaker: TOOFER
dialogues.text: Martin Van Buren?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Ron Jeremy? Josh is playful, unfazed by their meanness.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: No, it was supposed to be your mom.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: No. My mom’s voice is way lower.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Lisa) Dude, can we at least send out for coffee?

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: Yeah, but I'm not treating. I just spent $600 on bagels. Wanna know why? NO ONE BITES.

dialogues.speaker: ALL
dialogues.text: Nah... no thanks... etc.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: Sarie, can we order some coffees?

dialogues.speaker: SARIE
dialogues.text: (laying on the couch) Yeah. I'll have a soy latte. Sarie goes back to her magazine. Lisa looks at her for a beat, then writes down the coffee order herself.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: Sarie, soy latte. Josh?

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Large oreo brownie mochaccino, please. With whipped cream.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: 23. Must be nice. Toofer?

dialogues.speaker: TOOFER
dialogues.text: Short non-fat Ethiopian Yergacheffe.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: That‘s what you are, isn’t it?

dialogues.speaker: TOOFER
dialogues.text: {ignores him) And if they don't have that blend then, please, just a steamed milk with a skoche of Amarretto syrup.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: You really are gross. Toofer smiles and tips an imaginary hat. e@ Frank?

dialogues.speaker: LISA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: A hamburger.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: That's not...

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: What? It's the same price.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: Fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete gently reprimanding Kenneth the page.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: --and you probably don't need to introduce the writers to the tour group.

dialogues.speaker: KENNETH
dialogues.text: I agree. I thought they would find it interesting, but they really did not. So I took them downstairs and showed them Debra Norville's private toilet--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kenneth addresses a large tour group outside her bathroom,

dialogues.speaker: KENNETH
dialogues.text: +..to be used by no one but her. Loud embarrassing toilet sounds emanate from within.

dialogues.speaker: KENNETH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oops!

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Yeah, it's been my experience, Kenneth, that people do best with as little information as possible. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: wo If you pass a celebrity with the tour group, just respect their privacy.

dialogues.speaker: KENNETH
dialogues.text: I don't know. Conan O'Brien gets real mad if I don't make a big fuss over him.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Okay, well, feel it out. Make eye contact with the person. Try to read their facial expression. Do they want the attention?

dialogues.speaker: KENNETH
dialogues.text: I promise I'll get it right, Mr. Hornberger.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: I'm sure you will.

dialogues.speaker: KENNETH
dialogues.text: (tearing up) I just love television so much.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: We all do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lisa and the writers are sitting around the table rewriting a sketch. But Lisa has stopped to tell them her bagel story.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: And I was, like, “Screw you! I’m buying all the bagels!” The boys are not impressed or interested.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: That's great. You should make that into a movie for the Lifetime Network.

dialogues.speaker: TOOFER
dialogues.text: “All the Bagels: The Lisa Lemon Story.“

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: Starring Linda Hunt. Okay, where were we? Frank reads a part aloud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  ‘s

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Bottom of 4, “Hey, kids, who wants a big bowl of Flakey-o’s?”

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: I don't like "Flakey-o's." What's a better fake cereal name?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Oat Bung?

dialogues.speaker: TOOPER
dialogues.text: Chocolate Log Jam.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: Cornholes?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Sugar Cornholes.

dialogues.speaker: TOOFER
dialogues.text: Frosted mini-guns.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: Meat Puffs?

dialogues.speaker: TOOFER
dialogues.text: Kashi Go Poo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete enters. Phone rings. Sarie answers it.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: Pete. Fake cereal name.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Branfuckers. [bleeped

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: We have a winner.

dialogues.speaker: SARIE
dialogues.text: Pete, they want you and Lisa on the 50th E£loor.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Who, Gary?

dialogues.speaker: TOOFER
dialogues.text: Get him to pay for my Samovar.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: T'll get it. I’1l get it right now. I’m S still fired up from my bagel incident. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca
Josh is passing through.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: {to Frank) What bagel incident?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: If you ask her, I will stab you.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: What do we want?

dialogues.speaker: TOOFER
dialogues.text: A coffee maker, coffee, and an array of milks.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Three cases of name-brand soda a day.

dialogues.speaker: SARIE
dialogues.text: Cable tv.

dialogues.speaker: TOOFER
dialogues.text: A snack basket.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Custom made Nikes with the name of the show on the tongue and our initials on the heel.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: Josh, bend it, don’t break it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete and Lisa wait for the elevator.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: Gary will give us all this, right?

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Of course he will. He's the nicest man in the world. Remember when he found that baby bird in the park?

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  12.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: c.U. of Gary Luderman, 50, a square-looking corporate guy in a suit. He is intently feeding a baby bird with an eye dropper.

dialogues.speaker: GARY LUDERMAN
dialogues.text: Hey, fella. Hey, fella. (smiles up to the camera) I‘m gonna name him Fella.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: (sings) Gary Luderman is the nicest man in the wooorld! They turn the corner into...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The whole place is under noisy renovation. Workmen everywhere. Pete and Lisa step in to see JACK DONAGHY, 45, handsome and impeccably dressed, kicks his way into the room through a partially ripped out wall.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: Where's Gary?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Gary's dead. I'm Jack Donaghy. New VP of development for NBC/GE/Universal/Vivendi/kmart.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: We own Kmart now?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: No, we don't. So why are you dressed like we do? Pete and Lisa look at their overly casual work clothes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josh, Toofer and Frank are working. Sarie answers the

dialogues.speaker: SARIE
dialogues.text: Friday Night Bits. (beat) This is Sarie. (exasperated) Mommy, why are you calling me?

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: (to Toofer) Are you guys just staring at the new receptionist or are you actually trying to levitate her with your minds?

dialogues.speaker: TOOFER
dialogues.text: Shhh, I have to hear this. They eavesdrop on Sarie.

dialogues.speaker: SARIE
dialogues.text: Of course I showed up for work. You don't have to, like, check on me all the time. (quietly) I took the helicopter.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: {to Josh) Her parents are some rich famous big shots and they got her this job because they want her to learn the value of work. Sarie takes out her gum, folds it in a dollar bill and throws it out.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Who are her parents?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: She won't say.

dialogues.speaker: TOOFER
dialogues.text: She says it would affect the way we treat her.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: No, I would still try to make out with her. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: She doesn't do it for me. My perfect woman is a standard size 12, still in her waitress uniform, with her kid asleep in the next room, The other two nod in reluctant agreement. That is kind of hot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kenneth is giving another tour.

dialogues.speaker: KENNETH
dialogues.text: Rockefeller Center was built in the 1930‘s by--anyone?

dialogues.speaker: TOURIST
dialogues.text: The Rockefellers? Kenneth throws the guy a piece of candy.

dialogues.speaker: KENNETH
dialogues.text: Correct. Studio 8E was constructed in 1951 for a show called “The Vicks Vap-o- Rub Fun Hour.” In the 1970's it was used for a talk show by a gentleman named Phil Donahoo, And now it’s home to the Jenna DeCarlo-- Kenneth sees JENNA DECARLO come off the elevator. He tries to assess her mood. She takes off her sunglasses and looks at Kenneth. She has a crazy wide-eyed expression that means, "Don't bother me." But her face is so animated and friendly that Kenneth can't "read" it. Kenneth smiles at Jenna. Jenna smiles/grimaces back. There is a back and forth moment of panic between Kenneth and Jenna as they try to interpret each others' expressions. Then, one of the tour group recognizes her--

dialogues.speaker: TOURIST 6
dialogues.text: Hey, that's Jenna DeCarlo!

dialogues.speaker: OTHERS
dialogues.text: Ooh, Jenna DeCarlo! Jenna! Etc. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  15. Flashbulbs. Jenna looks hung-over and disheveled. The exact opposite of her picture on the standee behind her. She can't help but blurt out her thoughts to the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: JENNA
dialogues.text: Hi, let me explain that I'm really hung over right now and that's why I look like this, But I'm not normally hung over on a Wednesday. I tried a new tapas restaurant in my neighborhood last night and the waiter recognized me so he kept giving me free mojitos-- which doesn't happen all the time, I'm not like, some gross famous person-- but he kept bringing them and I don't usually drink hard liquor cause I'm really small and I can get drunk so easily-- (she starts to giggle with embarrassment ) I mean, I don't get drunk frequently. She grabs the arm of a tourist for emphasis.

dialogues.speaker: JENNA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'm just saying that if I look a little green there are extenuating circumstances.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: denna exits around a corner. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: KENNETH
dialogues.text: How about that? Jenna DeCarlo, every-- Jenna comes back around.

dialogues.speaker: JENNA
dialogues.text: But I don't want people to think I'm not friendly. I'm just nauseous and I have stomach issues-- The group nods politely.

dialogues.speaker: JENNA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Okay. She starts to exit.

dialogues.speaker: JENNA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Forget I said "stomach issues." Okay. Bye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  16.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete and Lisa sit gingerly on the edge of the couch. Workmen work behind them. Jack sits at his desk which has a lot of exposed wires hanging over it. Nearby we see the legs of a workman on a ladder.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: I'm surprised you're renovating. This is such a nice office.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: It’s a great office. But sometimes you have to change things that are perfectly good just to make them your own. Pete and Lisa look a little worried. Jack's nerdy MALE ASSISTANT appears and hands Jack a note written on a post-it.

dialogues.speaker: JACK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: T'1l call her back. Is she at the White House number?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Assistant nods. He hands him another post-it.

dialogues.speaker: JACK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Tell them I need a 4 a.m. tee time. He hands him another post-it.

dialogues.speaker: JACK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: About five inches, but it's thick. Pete and Lisa look at each other. As he exits, the assistant gets a little shock to the head from a dangling wire and flinches slightly. Jack turns his attention to Pete and Lisa.

dialogues.speaker: JACK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Are you familiar with the award-winning GE Tri-vection oven?

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: I don't cook very much,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. I got you. New York third wave feminist. College-educated. Single and pretending to be happy about it. Over- scheduled, under-sexed. You buy any Magazine that says "healthy body image" on the cover, but your kitchen's got nothing but Snackwelis and expired yogurts. You reject traditional female roles, but every two years you take up knitting for a week.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: (impressed) That's dead on.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: Are you gonna guess my weight now?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: You don’t want me to do that.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: That knitting thing is just uncanny. How do you do that?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Market research, my friend. Years and years of market research... that lead to my greatest triumph, the Tri-vection oven.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: My wife wants one of those. The assistant reappears. Another post-it to read.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (to the assistant) Yes, but I'll need my kevlar vest. (back to Pete and Lisa with a smile) The Trivection oven cooks perfect food five times faster than a conventional oven, because it uses three kinds of heat: thermal technology, for consistent temperature; GE Precise Air™ convection technology, for optimal air circulation; and microwave technology, for unbelievable speed. With three kinds of heat, you can cook a turkey in 22 minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  18.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Wow. That’s impressive.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: The people upstairs agree. That‘s why they promoted me. That’s why I’m here to re-tool your show.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: Re-tool what now?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I'm the new Vice President of East Coast Television and Microwave Oven Programming.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: That sounds like you program microwave ovens.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (to his asst.) See, I told you that was imprecise. Make it "Vice President of East Coast Television Programming and Microwave Oven- to x LISA me Czar?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I like you. You have the boldness of a much younger woman. Lisa is offended. Some sparks literally fly, from the construction behind her.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: You know, Jack, Lisa and I have worked together on a bunch of shows over the last ten years, and I know Gary was very pleased--

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Pete, I've seen the show. The little gal‘s good.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: Jenna.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: And the skits are decent, but you're missing that third kind of heat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  sane!

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: There's the kind of heat that rises from dog poop. Maybe we could use that.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Think about Lawrence Jordan.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: The black guy?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: The black movie star. I flew with him recently on a private jet to the Super - Bowl, and he was very entertaining.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: Isn't he, um... crazy?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Lawrence has had his problems in the last few years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: African-American comedy star LAWRENCE JORDAN, 35, runs down through traffic in nothing but tighty whities.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: Lama jedi! I ama jedi!

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: But it's important to remember that he was never charged with any crime. It's not illegal to fall asleep on your neighbor's roof.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Nor should it be.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Lawrence Jordan is the "third heat."

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: So would he join the cast...? Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Join the cast, permanent guest host-- I’m going to meet with him this afternoon and see what he thinks-- Lisa clears a place to lay down on the coffee table.

dialogues.speaker: JACK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: Sometimes when IT have these stress dreams, if I go to sleep in the dream, I come out of it. The Assistant scribbles then hands her a post-it.

dialogues.speaker: LISA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (reads) "This is not a dream."

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Jonathan, take Pete and help him pick out a Trivection oven for his wife.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: (pleased) Hey.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: Wait. Lisa takes out her list. LISA (CONT’D) We also want a coffee machine, a snack basket --

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Done. Jonathan? The assistant takes her list of demands. After he and Pete exit... JACK (CONT‘D) Lisa, I’ve heard a lot of good things about you.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: Well, a lot of that stuff I don’t do anymore. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I just want you to know that your job is secure. You’re gonna be essential to transforming the’ show.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: No, no, no, Jack. Jenna is my friend and we like our show the way it is. It may not get the highest ratings, but we have our own little following, and I'm not going to let you come in here and turn it into some kind of--

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Hit?

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: Just let me talk to her before you make any concrete-- The wall behind her comes tumbling down. A chunk of drywall hits her on the head. LISA (CONT’D) Mother-effer-! She falls down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A sketch from the show. Josh wears a fake moustache. Jenna is performing a crazy character with a goofy voice.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Yes, I have an appointment with Louise.

dialogues.speaker: JENNA
dialogues.text: Glouise isn’t here. I’m Bevergly. Recognition applause. This is a recurring character. JENNA (CONT’D) And I'll be your substitute hair styglist! Laughter.

dialogues.speaker: PULL BACK TO REVEAL
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca
INT. WRITER’S ROOM - AFTERNOON Toofer and Frank are watching a tape of this sketch.

dialogues.speaker: TOOFER
dialogues.text: We should do one where “Bevergly” is a “grape” counselor. Toofer hands him a frothy cappuccino in a glass mug. Across the room, Josh is going through a large snack basket.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: dust tell me who your parents are.

dialogues.speaker: SARIE
dialogues.text: No. You couldn't handle it.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Okay, I'm gonna try to guess who they are from looking at your face. He studies her.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Blond hair, little nose, kind of Swedish... Your mom is... Cheryl Tiegs and your dad is... (checks out her body) Stephen Hawking. Sarie punches him in the arm.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What? Cause you're smart!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete is talking to Kenneth again.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: ...and Jenna DeCarlo was very upset.

dialogues.speaker: KENNETH
dialogues.text: I tried to read her face, but it’s so rubbery! Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  ‘ How bout this? As a rule, if you see a celebrity when you’re with the tour group, do not bother them.

dialogues.speaker: KENNETH
dialogues.text: Is that a guideline, or a rule? Cause I respond well to structure.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Let’s say it’s a rule.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lisa gets off the elevator holding an ice pack to her head. She runs smack into Jenna. Lisa acts weird and

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: awkward.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: JENNA
dialogues.text: Hey. What happened to your head?

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: The sky is falling. Do you have a minute?

dialogues.speaker: JENNA
dialogues.text: No. I have a costume fitting for the “Judgemental Baby” sketch.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: . Abh. 1I’11 find you after.

dialogues.speaker: JENNA
dialogues.text: You seem upset.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: You seem upset.

dialogues.speaker: JENNA
dialogues.text: I‘m hung over.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: (seemingly reminiscing) Remember, like, five years ago when you were still waitressing and I was temping at that law firm and we used to do improv shows for free at night? f Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. JENNA

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: Did we hate it?

dialogues.speaker: JENNA
dialogues.text: Yeah. We hated it a lot.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: That’s what I thought. INT. WRITER’S ROOM - CONTINUOUS Lisa enters to find everyone excitedly enjoying the new high-end coffee machine, snack basket, cable tv, etc. Toofer hands her a cappuccino.

dialogues.speaker: TOOFER
dialogues.text: Well done, m’ lady!

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: How’d you get everything so fast?

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: What can I say? I‘m a hardass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She ducks into Pete's office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is finishing up a phone call.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Well, my condolences. Please let me know where we can send flowers. Okay. He hangs up. PETE (CONT’D) Ugh, poor Gary.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: How did he die?

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Killed by a deer.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: He used to feed the deer every morning at his house upstate. And then he got an injunction from the township saying he had to stop. So he did. Two days later, he goes out to get his paper, and the deer go mad. Pete makes an accompanying hand gesture like deer paws clawing at someone.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: They just went mad? She mimics the same gesture. Pete nods and does it again.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: He stopped feeding them and they turned on him.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: What are we gonna do? We quit, right? Do we quit?

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Not me. My twins need braces.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: The older twins or the identicals?

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: All four. They've got mouths like piranhas. He hands her a picture from his desk.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: Ew. They do.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: But sometimes with a thing like this, if you wait it out, it goes away on its own.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: {still looking at the picture) No, you gotta get the braces.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Jack Donaghy, I'm talking about. So he meets with crazy Lawrence Jordan today. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: PETE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Jordan'11 ask for too much money or he'll show up wearing a child's swimsuit and a shower cap and Donaghy will change his mind. Nobody needs to know this ever came up. Josh enters.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Oh, hey, awesome. Just the people I was looking for. I'm working on this bit about celebrities doing commercials, like- (imitates Christopher Walken perfectly) "This is Christopher Walken for Tropicana orange juice. Try the juice. It’s very... tangy” Or, um-- {imitates Lawrence Jordan perfectly) “Yo, this is Lawrence Jordan, star of ‘Black Cop/White. Cop' and when I want a good night's sleep, I sleep on my neighbor's roof. But now that I'm making a comeback, I sleep at the Best Western. Best Western. It's like sleeping on Ted Danson's roof. Holla!"

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: Okay, I don't know what you've heard, but Lawrence Jordan is not joining the cast. He is not taking over for Jenna. We are not turning into The Lawrence Jordan Show.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: What? She realizes he didn't know any of this.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Nicely handled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kenneth is answering questions from another tour group.

dialogues.speaker: KENNETH
dialogues.text: Yes, Katie Couric is real tiny in person. (stage whisper) (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: KENNETH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But her boobs are a lot bigger than you would think. The elevator doors open and LAWRENCE JORDAN, 30, enters with a small entourage, looking totally kickass. Cool music under. As they get close to the tour group, Kenneth sees Lawrence [a big movie star!] and, panicking, diverts the group's attention. KENNETH (CONT’D) Now, if y'all look over here, you'll see a water fountain! Lawrence stops behind the group and waits for Kenneth to acknowledge him. Kenneth starts to sweat.

dialogues.speaker: KENNETH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Does anyone have any questions about it? Lawrence gives his posse a look like, "What the hell? Why isn't this guy acknowledging me?"

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: Yes, I have a question. (big smile) How do you feel, NBC Tour? Cause you look like a portay!

dialogues.speaker: KENNETH
dialogues.text: (timidly) Lawrence Jordan, everybody. The group applauds excitedly to see Lawrence. Lawrence goes over and works the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: (To a pregnant lady) You're beautiful, little Mama. You're doing God's work. (Talks in a "honky" voice to a middle aged white guy) Don't I know you from the insurance meeting? We've got to sign those papers, Reginald. The guy laughs. Lawrence goes to a skinny, sullen, white teen. Lawrence puts his arm around the kid very sincerely. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  28. o u

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Listen. I know being your age is hard. But don't you "put on the trench coat.” You hear me? You have a problem, you call me. Don't put on that trench coat. The kid nods.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to everyone) Live. Life. Love. Laugh! The group applauds. There is such a thing as "star quality."

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Does Jenna know?

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: I gotta tell her before she hears it somewhere else.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: She's been around the block. She can handle bad news.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: Yeah... Off Lisa's look... cur TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The waitress serves Jenna her breakfast.

dialogues.speaker: JENNA
dialogues.text: (dejected) I said wheat toast. She bursts into tears.

dialogues.speaker: CUT BACK TO
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  «

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: She's gonna freak out. Toofer enters, indignant.

dialogues.speaker: TOOFER
dialogues.text: I will not work with Lawrence Jordan.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: It's just a rumor.

dialogues.speaker: TOOFER
dialogues.text: I worked with him at the MTV awards two years ago, where he found it endlessly amusing to show me his johnson.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: How was it?

dialogues.speaker: TOOFER
dialogues.text: Considerable. On one occasion, he had placed it in a foot-long hot dog bun and put mustard on it. I loathe him. Sarie stands in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: SARIE
dialogues.text: He's not that bad. He rents near us in East Hampton. I saw him once at a charity polo match.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Did he seem crazy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Well... he was making out with Martha Stewart...but we’ve all done that. They all stare at her for a beat. SARIE (CONT’D} Joking.

dialogues.speaker: TOOFER
dialogues.text: Have you seen any of his movies? The guy's sensibility is just cretinous.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: I saw the one where he plays, like, five different characters. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: poy ae 30.

dialogues.speaker: TOOFER
dialogues.text: "Black Cop/White Cop"

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: “Who Dat Ninja?"

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: No, he was... god, they all blend together, don't they? He had to pretend to be an old lady--

dialogues.speaker: TOOFER
dialogues.text: Yes, yes. He actually says the title at one point... Off their thinking... cuT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A clip from one of Lawrence Jordan's movies. He is dressed as a big fat white grandma a la Mrs. Doubtfire. Unseen parties are throwing pies at him.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: Oh, gracious goodness! You hooligans better watch out! A pie hits him. He suddenly sounds masculine and black.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Cause this honky grandma be trippin!

dialogues.speaker: LISA/TOOFER
dialogues.text: (relieved to remember} "Honky Grandma Be Trippin’."

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah. That movie was hilarious. Lisa glares at him. Frank bursts in, incredulous. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Is what I heard true?!

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Not

dialogues.speaker: PRANK
dialogues.text: Gary Luderman got killed by a deer?!

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Oh yeah, by the way, everybody. Gary Luderman got killed by a deer. Before anyone can react, Jenna enters. She is ina ridiculous baby costume [over-sized diaper, pinafore, bonnet] .

dialogues.speaker: JENNA
dialogues.text: You guys, you have to come see this! You know that crazy actor guy from “Who Dat Ninja?" He's in our studio! It's hilarious! You have to see it. Jenna runs out. They all run out after her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every face is pressed up against the picture window of the studio. They look shocked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lawrence Jordan paces around the homebase set, preaching to the empty seats.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: I'm back, America! I'm coming into your house. Lawrence grabs the camera and talks into the lens like Bono.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'm coming into your house, Americal Jack encourages him proudly from the empty seats.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: We love you, Lawrence! Come into our homes! Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca
Lawrence removes his shirt.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: I'm the third heat! I'm the third heat!

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: You're the third heat, baby! Out by the picture window, Jenna turns to Lisa, chuckling.

dialogues.speaker: JENNA
dialogues.text: This guy's full-tilt nuts. Am I right? Kenneth arrives with a tour group.

dialogues.speaker: KENNETH
dialogues.text: Here we see the set for “Friday Night Bits.” (stage whisper) . Although the industry buzz is it's being re-tooled into The Lawrence Jordan Sh-- Pete leaps over and chokes Kenneth to shut him up. The tour group gasps. Jenna turns to Lisa.

dialogues.speaker: JENNA
dialogues.text: What did he say?

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: Jenna, I have some news. Don't freak out. Jenna stares at her wide-eyed for a beat, then... cuT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jenna, in the baby costume, running through traffic [much like Lawrence Jordan], out of her mind.

dialogues.speaker: JENNA
dialogues.text: I ama jedi! I ama jedi!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone's gathered around Lawrence Jordan, he’s holding court. Lisa watches from the balcony above. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now at the time, me and Eddie were both talking to the same girl, ‘cept I didn’t know she was a transexual... Everyone laughs.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: (to herself) Will not one of you stand with me? Jack Donaghy walks over to her.

dialogues.speaker: LISA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Would you like me to review for you everything you've done wrong so far? You’ve hired a guy so crazy that nobody else in the world will work with him right now. You brought him in here without even talking to Jenna first, which will send her into a two-year spiral. You’re putting him in my hands, knowing I don’t want him here. You gave my greedy, insatiable writing staff every toy they asked for, which only means they will have a longer list of things they want tomorrow. Don't stop feeding those deer, Mr. Donaghy, or they will turn on you.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: You'll make it work.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: What makes you think that?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Cause your friend Jenna’s got nowhere else to go. You'll be nice to Lawrence, cause it’s not his fauit. And you’ll focus all your rage and hatred on me.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: Ugh, you know what? You don’t know everything about me. She storms out of frame. Jack watches her walk away.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: About 127 pounds. From off camera, she whips a water bottle at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  34.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She climbs down into the studio to introduce herself to Lawrence Jordan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, I’m Lisa. I’m--

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: Yes, yes. Lisa Lemon! I know who you are. He kisses her hands, dramatically. LAWRENCE (CONT‘D) The very talented. Very talented.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: Oh, well. Let‘’s not.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: You/re gonna be my Phil Spector, right?

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: How's that?

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: You're gonna take my raw black sound and make it nice for white people’s ears.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: Yes. And then I’m gonna kill somebody. Lawrence thinks this is hilarious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lisa, enters and approaches the maitre’d.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: Hi, I’m here to pick up my baby. He points to Jenna, still in the baby outfit, in a back booth, wasted.

dialogues.speaker: JENNA
dialogues.text: Tadeo, another mojito!

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: No, no. Come on, friend. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca
Lisa struggles to help Jenna out. She stops by a couple with a baby near the door. LISA (CONT’D) Can I borrow this for five minutes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lisa pushes Jenna down the street in a stroller.

dialogues.speaker: JENNA
dialogues.text: I have so much rage.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: It could be worse. You could have nipple confusion. (OUT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca
